summary: Custom commands allow you to create reusable workflows triggered with a / prefix in the chat input. Commands are defined as plain Markdown files and can be stored at project, global, or team levels.
key_takeaways: Project commands are stored in .cursor/commands directory.
Global commands are stored in ~/.cursor/commands directory.
Team commands are created by admins in the Cursor Dashboard and automatically available to all members.
Commands are triggered by typing / followed by the command name in chat.

questions.question: How do you trigger a custom command in Cursor's chat?

options.text: Type @ followed by the command name
Type / followed by the command name
Type ! followed by the command name
Type # followed by the command name

questions.explanation: Commands are triggered by typing / in the chat input, which will display available commands from all locations (project, global, and team).

questions.question: What file format are Cursor commands written in?
questions.explanation: Commands are defined as plain Markdown files with descriptive names (e.g., review-code.md, write-tests.md). The Markdown content describes what the command should do.

questions.question: How can you provide additional context to a command when using it?

options.text: You cannot - commands run exactly as defined
Edit the command file before each use
Type additional text after the command name, which gets included in the prompt
Create a new command for each variation

questions.explanation: You can provide additional context by typing after the command name. For example, '/commit and /pr these changes to address DX-523' includes extra context alongside the command.
